Akita is the largest city in the prefecture, and as such is the hub for transportation, sports, and shopping.  Its longitude is about the middle of the prefecture, and so is reachable from both the north and south.

In Akita, late June to late July is the rainy season.  The spring and summer before and after that tend to have fairly moderate amounts of rain, and are good for outdoor activities.  In November, it is common for some cold weather thunder storms to occur—this is said to mark the end of fall and the beginning of
(a local fish) season.  In the winter, Akita sees some snow, though certainly inland areas get more.
Akita has an airport, with domestic flights coming in from such places as
. Buses connect the airport with Akita Station (秋田駅) -- a ride costs ¥980 and takes 40 minutes.

Akita Shinkansen service from Tokyo to Akita resumed on April 29, but trains have to slow down around areas where repairs are being made. Allow an extra hour or so if traveling between these two cities.}}

The
provides hourly service from Tokyo station to Akita station.  These trains, called the
(こまち) trains, have only reserved seating. The Komachi stops at Ueno, Omiya,
before slowing down to travel to Shizukuishi, Tazawako,

, Omagari, and finally Akita over conventional rail lines. Trains also reverse direction once at Omagari, the stop before Akita.  Komachi trains from Tokyo reach Akita in four hours and cost ¥16,800 each way. Beware that the Komachi trains are coupled to

-bound Hayate trains, which split at Morioka, but as all seats are reserved the chance of getting in the wrong car is minimal at best. For foreign tourists traveling from Tokyo, the better deal is to purchase a
stops in Akita before terminating in
station also stops here, but the
will only run seasonally starting in March of 2014.

Odakyu and Akita Chuo Kotsu run the
alt=新日本海フェリー 秋田フェリーターミナル
content=SNF has ferries going north and south.  Two ferries go to
.  Both of those towns are relatively close to
.  To the south the ferries go to

).  Reservations can be made in English by email.  For Golden Week and busy times, ferries fill up weeks or months in advance.  These ferries accommodate passengers with or without vehicles, though the ferry terminals may be inconveniently located for passengers on foot.

You can get around by bus, taxi, car, or bike.  Many bus routes start in front of Akita Station.  In the winter, there can be snow and ice, so drivers should decrease their speed.

value: content=Senshū Park is a beautiful place to take a walk, especially during the spring season when the
are blooming. The park hosts a replica of
, the original having been constructed in 733AD. For a small admission fee, the lower floors of the castle contain a small museum, and the upper floor provides a panoramic view of the city.
content=This museum, built in 1912, hosts various exhibitions of arts, crafts, and historical materials.
directions=In Atorion Music Hall, south of Senshū Park and west of Akita Station.
content=This museum has Akita-related art on display year-round.  From time to time, various exhibitions are here, too.
alt=秋田県立博物館; Akita Kenritsu Hakubutsukan
directions=NE of Oiwake Station, east of Kanaashi Agricultural High School.
content=This museum has hands-on exhibits on science and history.
name=Masakichi Hirano Museum of Fine Art
alt=平野政吉美術館; Hirano Masakichi Bijutsukan
directions=South of Senshū Park, next to the Prefectural Art Museum.
hours=May-Sep 10AM-5:30PM, Oct-Apr 10AM-5PM, closed Mondays, closed Dec 28-Jan 3
content=This museum, built in 1967, focuses on the works of Tsuguji Foujita.
content=A small local zoo with a giraffe, elephant, monkeys, lesser pandas, camels, and other animals.
alt=ラウンドワンスタジアム秋田店
directions=From the brown JA Building, follow Highway 13 south.  Round One is on the corner next to McDonald's.

content=Round One is a kind of indoor amusement park.  You pay by how long you want inside.  Once you're inside, there are basketball courts, roller skates, a soccer turf, lots of video games, and similar things.
directions=Near the intersection of Highway 41 and Highway 61, 4km south of the Akita Red Cross Hospital.
content=This is the largest mall in Akita.  There are many chain stores.  In particular, there's a foreign foods store, and also a movie theater showing many movies in English.
price=Regular price ¥2000; seniors, students, ladies on Wednesday, men on Thursday, morning shows, late shows, one's birthday, first day of the month ¥1000
content=This theater is the largest in the prefecture.  Some of its foreign films are in English with Japanese subs.  See the website for details.
hours=M-Sa 10AM-8PM, Su 10AM-6:30PM, excepting occasional days off
content=This store sells wine, beer, cheese, and scotch.
directions=A block SW of Akita Station.
content=This store has a small selection of cigars.  The owner can do special orders, if you ask.

The most well-known Akita dish is
. Kiritanpo is essentially a tube made of rice, generally formed around a disposable chopstick. It is often roasted, sometimes after being smothered in miso paste. It is also eaten in

, a stew of sliced kiritanpo, vegetables, and chicken or fish, most commonly eaten during the winter.  Of course, there are many non-local styles of food available in Akita City, including a wide variety of ramen and Indian restaurants.

value: directions=From the Akita Prefectural Office, go a block east and a half block north.
content=Serves tasty tantanmen.  Several Japanese magazines rank Ebiya as the second best ramen shop in Akita.
directions=From Senshū Park, take Highway 28 east for 2km.  From the Lawson, go south 1 block.  The restaurant is on the corner at the traffic light.
directions=From the intersection between Yabase Park and the Akita Prefectural Office, go two traffic lights north and 1 block east.  Peacock is on the corner.
content=One of the top Indian restaurants in Akita.  Vegetarian options available.
directions=On Highway 233, several kilometers NW of Akita University.  Across from Sunkus.
content=This is a small Indian restaurant.  The nan is all you can eat, and quite tasty.  The curry selection is rather large, and tasty too.
alt=らーめん錦 秋田本店
directions=By car, go north from the large post office on Highway 56.  After about 6 kilometers, turn right on Highway 72.  The ramen shop is on the left after about 2 kilometers.
content=This is a branch of Odate's famous Ramen Nishiki.  That ramen shop is ranked as the best in Akita, and this branch is also quite good.  Another branch is located south of Yabase Park.
alt=らーめん錦 秋田分店
directions=From the Prefectural Library, go south.  The shop is on the right, between the 3rd and 4th traffic light.  It's the second building on a side street, so look carefully.
content=This is a branch of Odate's famous Ramen Nishiki.  That ramen shop is ranked as the best in Akita, and this branch is also quite good.  Another branch is in northern Akita City.
alt=末廣ラーメン本舗秋田山王店
directions=Just east of the Akita City Office, a block north of Sanno Odori.
hours=10:30AM-3PM, 5PM-2AM, closed Tuesdays, closed the 3rd Wednesday of each month
content=Delicious ramen.  Another branch is near Akita Station.
alt=末廣ラーメン本舗秋田駅前店
directions=SE of Akita Station, just west of Hotel Alpha One.
content=Delicious ramen.  Another branch is near the Akita City Office.
directions=5 blocks south of the Akita Sky Hotel on Sanno Odori.
content=This restaurant is known for its tsukemen.
directions=On the south side of eastbound Chuo Dori, 5 traffic lights west of Akita Station.
content=This Mexican restaurant has tacos, enchiladas, other Mexican food, and a large selection of alcohol.  The tacos are made with corn tortillas.
directions=A 15 minute walk from Akita Station.
content=This is a Belgium-themed cafe.  Sometimes it has live music in the evening.
alt=レストラン プラッツ
directions=A block NE of Hotel Pearl City, 2 blocks SW of Senshu Park.
content=A restaurant and microbrewery.  The portions are small, and the drinks are large.

As one of Japan's most famous rice-growing regions, Akita has some of the best local sake in all of Japan.  A great place to find many different bottles for sale (and usually free samples) is in the Prefectural Goods Shop in the basement of the Atorion Concert Hall.

Some travelers sleep in their cars, and if you can find a quiet area, this is typically not a problem.  However, if you drink in the evening and sleep in your car, it is a good to use a personal breathalyzer before driving the next morning – even a small amount of alcohol in your system makes driving illegal, and the police are known to watch for people who have slept in their cars.
